Mr Stumpf, 63, who was twice called in front of Congress to testify about the scandal in recent weeks, faced vocal demands to resign from an outraged public, but the timing of his departure was unexpected given that the Wells Fargo board had not completed its internal investigation into the phony accounts and that the bank reports   earnings on Friday.

The departure is a stunning reversal of fortune for Stumpf, who successfully navigated Wells through the financial crisis and built it into the world’s most valuable bank with a focus on Main   lending that was the envy of Wall Street.

” Stumpf’s downfall began in early September when Wells Fargo was fined $185 million by regulators after it discovered that thousands of employees were setting up unauthorized accounts, including credit cards and checking accounts, customers had not requested.

Wells Fargo has been under fire from irate customers, regulators, lawmakers and former employees since last month, when it disclosed that it would pay $185 million in fines and penalties over the unauthorized creation of as many as two million bank and credit card accounts over a period of at least five years by branch employees who were said to be under intense pressure to hit ambitious product sales goals.
In September, the bank agreed to pay $185 million to settle charges that it had opened as many as 2 million accounts without the knowledge or approval of customers.
Wells Fargo’s chief executive and chairman, John Stumpf, is retiring effective immediately from both the bank and the board in the wake of the scandal over its sales practices.

Wells Fargo & Co’s veteran chairman and chief executive officer, John Stumpf, abruptly departed on Wednesday bowing to  pressure over its sales tactics that has damaged the bank’s reputation and put Wall Street under renewed scrutiny.

Wells Fargo announced Wednesday that its longtime chief executive and chairman, John G Stumpf, is stepping down, the latest turn for the embattled megabank after it admitted that thousands of   employees had set up sham accounts to meet sales quotas.

The chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo  Co. John Stumpf, has resigned effective immediately in the aftermath of a scandal over the bank’s past practice of secretly selling services to unsuspecting customers.
The scandal engulfing Wells Fargo toppled its chairman and chief executive on Wednesday, as John G Stumpf announced his departure from the company, effective immediately.
The bank is splitting the role of chairman and CEO with Stephen Sanger, its lead director, becoming chairman.

Tim Sloan, another   Wells Fargo executive, will take over Stumpf’s duties as CEO A board member, Stephen Sanger, will now serve as chairman, effectively dividing power that had previously been consolidated under Stumpf.
Stephen Sanger, the Wells Fargo board’s lead director, was elected to serve as the board’s   chairman.
Stumpf will be replaced by President and Chief Operating Officer Timothy Sloan, long considered to be Stumpf’s eventual successor.
